description:
Salmo trutta, commonly known as the brown trout, is a species of freshwater fish belonging to the family Salmonidae. It is native to Europe and western Asia, and has been introduced to various regions around the world for recreational fishing and aquaculture.

The brown trout is a medium-sized fish, typically ranging from 20 to 80 cm in length, with a lifespan of up to 15 years. It has a robust, streamlined body shape and a distinctive brown or golden coloration, with dark spots and red or orange spots along its sides. The brown trout is an opportunistic predator, feeding on a variety of aquatic insects, crustaceans, small fish, and even small rodents or birds.

Salmo trutta is an important game fish and is widely sought after by anglers for its excellent fighting abilities and culinary qualities. It is also a popular target for conservation efforts, as some populations have been threatened by factors such as habitat degradation, overfishing, and the introduction of non-native species.
